sentences.zh: 贊曰：臣之姑充後宮為婕妤，父子昆弟侍帷幄，數為臣言成帝善修容儀，升車正立，不內顧，不疾言，不親指，臨朝淵嘿，尊嚴若神，可謂穆穆天子之容者矣！

translations.literal: Appraisal says: My aunt filled the rear palace as Consort Jieyu; father, sons, and brothers served in the bedchamber curtains; they frequently told me Emperor Cheng was good at cultivating his appearance and bearing, ascending the carriage standing upright, not looking back, not speaking hastily, not pointing personally, facing the court in profound silence, dignified like a god—one could call him the dignified bearing of a solemn Son of Heaven!
translations.idiomatic: Appraisal: My aunt served in the rear palace as Consort Jieyu; father, sons, and brothers served in the emperor's private quarters. They frequently told me Emperor Cheng excelled at cultivating his appearance and bearing—ascending carriages standing upright, never looking back, never speaking hastily, never pointing personally, facing court in profound silence, dignified like a god. One could truly call him the solemn bearing of a Son of Heaven!

translations.literal: Appraisal: My aunt served in the rear palace as Consort Jieyu; father, sons, and brothers served in the emperor's private quarters. They frequently told me Emperor Cheng excelled at cultivating his appearance and bearing—ascending carriages standing upright, never looking back, never speaking hastily, never pointing personally, facing court in profound silence, dignified like a god. One could truly call him the solemn bearing of a Son of Heaven! He broadly surveyed ancient and modern times, and accommodated straightforward words.
